description: From French crochet, from Middle French crochet, from Old French crochet, crokét (“curved instrument, hook”), diminutive of Old French croc (“hook”), from Old Frankish *krōk (“hook”) or from Old Norse krókr (“hook, bend, bight”), both from Proto-Germanic *krōkaz (“hook”), from Proto-Indo-European *gerg- (“tracery, basket, twist”). Cognate with Middle English crōc (“crook, hook”), Middle Dutch croec, crōc (“curl”). Doublet of crocket, croquet, and crotchet. More at crook, crooked.

entries.meaning: Needlework made by looping thread with a hooked needle.
A certain crest of enamel on the molar teeth of some rhinoceroses.

verbs.description: crochet (third-person singular simple present crochets, present participle crocheting, simple past and past participle crocheted)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To make (a piece of) needlework using a hooked needle; to make interlocking loops of thread.
